metadata.title: UK Democracy for Young Citizens
metadata.description: Simple, clear questions about UK democracy for children aged 12+
metadata.subject: UK Democracy and Government

questions.question: What does 'democracy' mean?
questions.explanation: Democracy comes from Greek words meaning 'people power'. In a democracy, the people choose their government by voting.

questions.question: At what age can you currently vote in UK general elections?
questions.explanation: You must be 18 to vote in UK general elections, though the government plans to lower this to 16 in the future.

questions.question: How many parts make up the UK Parliament?
choices: Two - House of Commons and House of Lords
Three - House of Commons, House of Lords, and the Monarch
One - just the House of Commons
questions.explanation: The UK Parliament has three parts: the House of Commons (elected MPs), the House of Lords (appointed members), and the Monarch.

questions.question: What do we call the person who leads the UK government?
questions.explanation: The Prime Minister leads the UK government. They are usually the leader of the political party with the most MPs.

questions.question: How many MPs are there in the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: There are 650 MPs in the House of Commons, each representing a different area of the UK called a constituency.

questions.question: What is the voting system used to elect UK MPs called?
questions.explanation: The UK uses First Past the Post. In each constituency, the candidate with the most votes wins and becomes the MP.

questions.question: Which of these is a key feature of democracy?
questions.explanation: Democracy means everyone who is eligible can vote freely to choose their representatives. Elections should be fair and open to all.

questions.question: What do MPs do in Parliament?
choices: Make laws, represent constituents, and question the government
Only vote on what the Prime Minister wants
questions.explanation: MPs represent their local area, help make new laws, and question the government to make sure it's doing a good job.

questions.question: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have their own:
choices: Parliaments or Assemblies with some powers
questions.explanation: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have devolved parliaments or assemblies that make decisions on some issues like health and education in their areas.

questions.question: What must you show when voting at a polling station?
questions.explanation: Since 2023, you must show photo ID when voting in person at elections in England. This includes passports, driving licences, or other accepted forms of photo ID.

questions.question: The House of Lords members are:
choices: All members of the Royal Family
questions.explanation: Most House of Lords members are life peers, appointed by the monarch on advice from the Prime Minister. They are not elected by the public.

questions.question: How often must UK general elections be held?
questions.explanation: UK general elections must happen at least every 5 years, but the Prime Minister can call one earlier if needed.

questions.question: What is a constituency?
choices: An area represented by one MP
questions.explanation: A constituency is a geographical area that elects one MP to represent them in the House of Commons. The UK has 650 constituencies.

questions.question: Who is the current head of state of the UK?
questions.explanation: King Charles III is the head of state. The UK is a constitutional monarchy where the monarch is the head of state but the Prime Minister leads the government.

questions.question: What happens if no political party wins a majority in an election?
questions.explanation: If no party wins a majority (more than half the seats), parties can work together in a coalition to form a government.
